Description: Dish, made of polychrome glazed pottery. The dish, which has a narrow angled rim, is painted in greyish-blue, black, pale green and bole red under a transparent greenish glaze with a multi-tiered pagoda-like tower set between tulips and other floral sprays. Rim with a radial inscription in Greek and the date May 1666; base left plain; foot only partially glazed.
Curator's comments: The vaguely exotic appearances of the tower and the suspended balls (or eggs?) in the arched openings offers a distant, probably fortuitous, reminiscent of the mosaic cycle of the Great Mosque of Damascus.
Bibliographic references: Atasoy & Raby 1989 / Iznik: The Pottery of Ottoman Turkey (fig.653)
Hobson 1932b / A Guide to the Islamic Pottery of the Near East (fig.109)
Denny 2004 / Iznik: The Artistry of Ottoman Ceramics (p.202)
Lane 1957 / Later Islamic Pottery: Persia, Syria, Egypt, Turkey (fig.47.B)
Akbarnia et al 2018 / The Islamic World: a History in Objects (p.161, fig.4)
Condition: Kiln grit and iron impurities in the glaze; glaze frits around the rim.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Sir Augustus Wollaston Franks
